title: How to Turn an Oversized T Shirt Into a Hot Mini Dress

steps.title: Choose a large T-shirt and turn it inside out.
steps.content: Choose a large T-shirt and turn it inside out. Pick a shirt that you won't mind cutting up. Make sure that it is long enough to cover your hips and upper thighs. Turn it inside out, then spread it out on a flat surface. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Trace a tank top onto the shirt, extending the hem to the bottom.
steps.content: Trace a tank top onto the shirt, extending the hem to the bottom. Choose a tank top that fits you, then set it down on top of the shirt. Make sure that the tank top is centered and that the shoulders align with those on the T-shirt. Trace the sides and straps onto the shirt. Be sure to extend the sides to the hem of the T-shirt. [2] X Research source If you don't have a tank top, you can use a fitted T-shirt instead. You are only tracing the sides and outside of the straps. Don't trace the collar or inside the straps. Tank tops taper towards the bottom. Be sure to continue tapering the lines towards the bottom edge of your T-shirt. Don't draw the sides straight down.

steps.title: Cut out your tracing, leaving a 1⁄2-inch (1.3-cm) seam allowance.
steps.content: Cut out your tracing, leaving a 1⁄2-inch (1.3-cm) seam allowance. Lift the tank top away, then cut 1 ⁄ 2 inch (1.3 cm) outside the lines that you drew. The shirt should still be intact along the shoulders and collar. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Sew up the sides of the shirt using a 1⁄2-inch (1.3-cm) seam allowance.
steps.content: Sew up the sides of the shirt using a 1⁄2-inch (1.3-cm) seam allowance. Pin the sides of the shirt together, then sew them on your sewing machine using a zigzag stitch and a matching thread color. Start just below the armpits and finish at the hem. Backstitch when you start and finish sewing to keep your stitches from coming undone. [4] X Research source If you don't know how to sew, use hot glue or fabric glue instead. Let the glue set before moving on. Remove the pins as you sew or glue the fabric.

steps.title: Hem the armholes if you want a nicer finish.
steps.content: Hem the armholes if you want a nicer finish. Fold and pin the raw, cut edges of the armholes down by 1 ⁄ 4 to 1 ⁄ 2 inch (0.64 to 1.27 cm). Sew the hems as close as possible to the raw, cut edge using a zigzag stitch and a matching thread color. Remember to backstitch when you start and finish sewing, and to remove the pins as you sew. [5] X Research source If you can't sew, use hot glue or fabric glue instead. Let the glue dry before moving on.

steps.title: Trim off any loose or hanging threads, if needed.
steps.content: Trim off any loose or hanging threads, if needed. Go over the seams and hems you just finished sewing. If you see any loose or hanging threads, cut them off with small scissors, as close to the fabric as possible. Skip this step if you used fabric glue. If you used hot glue, look for any whisker-like strands of hot glue, and pull those off.

steps.title: Turn the shirt right-side-out, then cut the collar off, if desired.
steps.content: Turn the shirt right-side-out, then cut the collar off, if desired. Once you turn your shirt right-side-out, you are technically done. For an added touch, you can cut the collar off. If you hemmed the armholes, you should hem the cut collar too. If you left the armholes raw, then you don't need to hem the cut collar. [6] X Research source If you want a fancier collar, you could cut the front into a V-neck or a scoop neck.

steps.title: Spread a large, baggy T-shirt on a flat surface.
steps.content: Spread a large, baggy T-shirt on a flat surface. Pick a large T-shirt that is at least 3 sizes too big for you. Make sure that you won't mind cutting it up, then spread it out on a flat surface. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Trace a tank top onto the shirt, leaving a 2-inch (5.1-cm) seam allowance.
steps.content: Trace a tank top onto the shirt, leaving a 2-inch (5.1-cm) seam allowance. Place a tank top that fits you on top of the shirt, with the shoulders matching up. Trace the sides of the shirt, leaving a 2-inch (5.1-cm) seam allowance. When you get to the armholes, draw straight lines that angle from armpits to shoulders. When you get to the bottom of the tank top, extend the lines to the bottom corners of the T-shirt. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Cut the shirt along the lines that you traced.
steps.content: Cut the shirt along the lines that you traced. Make sure that you cut through both layers of the T-shirt. Do not cut apart the shoulders or collar of the shirt. Don't worry if the cut-out shapes look too big and baggy for you. You'll fix that in a moment. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Cut a 2-inch (5.1-cm) deep fringe into the sides of the shirt.
steps.content: Cut a 2-inch (5.1-cm) deep fringe into the sides of the shirt. Make the slits 1 ⁄ 2 to 1 inch (1.3 to 2.5 cm) wide and 2 inches (5.1 cm) deep on each side of the shirt. Start cutting at the bottom hem and finish cutting at the armpits. [10] X Research source Cut through both layers of fabric at the same time so that the fringes match up. Do not cut a fringe into the armholes.

steps.title: Tie the front fringe to the back fringe.
steps.content: Tie the front fringe to the back fringe. Take the first tassel on the front of the shirt, and tie it to the first tassel on the back of the shirt in a tight, double-knot. Work your way up the side of the shirt, then do the other side. [11] X Research source If the fringes are too short for you, gently pull on them to stretch them out first. If you don't want the fringe to be visible, turn the shirt inside out first. Remember to turn it right-side-out when you are done.

steps.title: Get a large T-shirt with a neck hole big enough to fit around your chest.
steps.content: Get a large T-shirt with a neck hole big enough to fit around your chest. You will be wearing the shirt with the neck around your chest, just below the armpits. The neck hole needs to be big enough to accommodate this. Something that is 3 sizes too big for you would be ideal. The shirt needs to be long enough to cover your hips and upper thighs.

steps.title: Put the shirt on and pull it under your armpits.
steps.content: Put the shirt on and pull it under your armpits. Pull your head, shoulders, and arms through the neck hole of the shirt. Tug the shirt down so that it sits around your chest, just below your armpits. The arms should be hanging loosely at your sides. If the shirt feels too tight, take it off. Cut the collar off, then put it back on again.

steps.title: Tie the arms behind your back if you want a simple look.
steps.content: Tie the arms behind your back if you want a simple look. Grab both arms of the T-shirt, and pull them behind your back. Tie them into a tight knot so that they cinch the extra fabric. If you are worried about the knot coming undone, tie a second knot. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Tie the arms in front of your chest if you want a cute look.
steps.content: Tie the arms in front of your chest if you want a cute look. Grab both arms and pull them in front of your chest. Tie them into a tight knot, right under your bust, so that they cinch the extra fabric. Leave the dress as-is, or pair it with a cute cardigan. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Tuck the arms into the shirt and wear a belt for an alternate look.
steps.content: Tuck the arms into the shirt and wear a belt for an alternate look. Tuck the arms into the shirt so that you can't see them anymore. Choose a belt that looks nice with your shirt, and wrap it around your waist. If you want to turn the sleeves into pockets, pull them out, then sew or safety-pin the sleeve openings shut. Tuck the sleeves back into the shirt when you are done. [14] X Research source The pockets will end up being a little above your waist. This all depends on how wide the shoulders of your T-shirt were.
